item.description:
"'He looked as if he would murder me, and he did." --from "The Portobello Road"

Few writers command so exhilarating a style playful and rigorous, cheerful and venomous, hilariously acute and coolly supernatural. Ranging from South Africa to the West End, her dazzling stories feature hanging judges, fortune-tellers, shy girls, psychiatrists, dress designers, pensive ghosts, imaginary chauffeurs, and persistent guests. Chance encounters between strangers spiral into unexpected plots (as when a young woman meets a soldier on a train in "The House of the Famous Poet"), and Spark's narrators (including the wry, level-headed ghost of "The Portobello Road") serve as astute observers of human relations.

"[Spark's writing is] likely to go on being read as long as fiction in English is read at all." -- The New York Times Book Review

"Profound art disguised as a lark." -- Kirkus Reviews

Please read and come prepared to discuss:

Bang-Bang You're Dead

Seraph and the Zambesi

The House of the Famous Poet

The Girl I Left Behind Me

Another Pair of Hands

group.name: Classic Books: Book Club for Die-hard Readers

item.name: Muriel Spark: Short Stories
